# Region

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

Two or three dimensionally defined space, mainly in terrestrial and
astrophysics sciences

This article is about the concept of region in geography. For other uses, see
[Region (disambiguation)](/wiki/Region_\(disambiguation\) "Region
\(disambiguation\)").

In [geography](/wiki/Geography "Geography"), **regions** are areas that are
broadly divided by physical characteristics ([physical
geography](/wiki/Physical_geography "Physical geography")), human impact
characteristics ([human geography](/wiki/Human_geography "Human geography")),
and the interaction of humanity and the environment ([environmental
geography](/wiki/Environmental_geography "Environmental geography")).
Geographic regions and sub-regions are mostly described by their imprecisely
defined, and sometimes transitory boundaries, except in human geography, where
[jurisdiction](/wiki/Jurisdiction_\(area\) "Jurisdiction \(area\)") areas such
as national borders are defined in law.

Apart from the [global](/wiki/Earth "Earth") [continental](/wiki/Continent
"Continent") regions, there are also [hydrospheric](/wiki/Hydrosphere
"Hydrosphere") and [atmospheric](/wiki/Atmosphere "Atmosphere") regions that
cover the [oceans](/wiki/Ocean "Ocean"), and discrete [climates](/wiki/Climate
"Climate") above the land and water masses of the planet. The land and water
global regions are divided into subregions geographically bounded by large
geological features that influence large-scale ecologies, such as
[plains](/wiki/Plain "Plain") and features.

As a way of describing spatial areas, the concept of regions is important and
widely used among the many branches of geography, each of which can describe
areas in regional terms. For example, ecoregion is a term used in
[environmental geography](/wiki/Environmental_geography "Environmental
geography"), cultural region in [cultural geography](/wiki/Cultural_geography
"Cultural geography"), bioregion in [biogeography](/wiki/Biogeography
"Biogeography"), and so on. The field of geography that studies regions
themselves is called [regional geography](/wiki/Regional_geography "Regional
geography").

In the fields of [physical geography](/wiki/Physical_geography "Physical
geography"), [ecology](/wiki/Ecology "Ecology"),
[biogeography](/wiki/Biogeography "Biogeography"),
[zoogeography](/wiki/Zoogeography "Zoogeography"), and [environmental
geography](/wiki/Environmental_geography "Environmental geography"), regions
tend to be based on natural features such as [ecosystems](/wiki/Ecosystem
"Ecosystem") or [biotopes](/wiki/Biotope "Biotope"), [biomes](/wiki/Biome
"Biome"), [drainage basins](/wiki/Drainage_basin "Drainage basin"), [natural
regions](/wiki/Natural_region "Natural region"), [mountain
ranges](/wiki/Mountain_range "Mountain range"), [soil types](/wiki/Soil_type
"Soil type"). Where [human geography](/wiki/Human_geography "Human geography")
is concerned, the regions and subregions are described by the discipline of
[ethnography](/wiki/Ethnography "Ethnography").

A region has its own nature that could not be moved. The first nature is its
natural environment (landform, climate, etc.). The second nature is its
physical elements complex that were built by people in the past. The third
nature is its socio-cultural context that could not be replaced by new
immigrants.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

## Globalization[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Region&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Globalization")]

[![Map of the
Earth](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Map_of_the_world_by_the_US_Gov_as_of_2016.svg/400px-
Map_of_the_world_by_the_US_Gov_as_of_2016.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Map_of_the_world_by_the_US_Gov_as_of_2016.svg
"Map of the Earth")

Global regions distinguishable from space, and are therefore clearly
distinguished by the two basic terrestrial environments, land and
[water](/wiki/Water "Water"). However, they have been generally recognised as
such much earlier by terrestrial [cartography](/wiki/Cartography
"Cartography") because of their impact on human geography. They are divided
into largest of land regions, known as [continents](/wiki/Continent
"Continent"), and the largest of water regions known as [oceans](/wiki/Ocean
"Ocean"). There are also significant regions that do not belong to either
classification, such as [archipelago](/wiki/Archipelago "Archipelago") regions
that are [littoral](/wiki/Littoral "Littoral") regions, or
[earthquake](/wiki/Earthquake "Earthquake") regions that are defined in
[geology](/wiki/Geology "Geology").

### Continental regions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Region&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Continental regions")]

Continental regions are usually based on broad experiences in human history
and attempts to reduce very large areas to more manageable
[regionalization](/wiki/Regionalization "Regionalization") for the purpose of
study. As such they are conceptual constructs, usually lacking distinct
boundaries. Oceanic division into maritime regions are used in conjunction
with the relationship to the central area of the continent, using directions
of the [compass](/wiki/Compass "Compass").

Some continental regions are defined by the major continental feature of their
identity, such as the [Amazon basin](/wiki/Amazon_basin "Amazon basin"), or
the [Sahara](/wiki/Sahara "Sahara"), which both occupy a significant
percentage of their respective continental land area.

To a large extent, major continental regions are mental constructs created by
considering an efficient way to define large areas of the continents. For the
most part, the images of the world are derived as much from academic studies,
the media[_[clarification needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify
"Wikipedia:Please clarify")_], or from personal experience of global
[exploration](/wiki/Exploration "Exploration"). They are a matter of
collective human knowledge of its own planet and are attempts to better
understand their environments.

### Regional geography[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Region&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Regional geography")]

[Regional geography](/wiki/Regional_geography "Regional geography") is a
branch of geography that studies regions of all sizes across the
[Earth](/wiki/Earth "Earth"). It has a prevailing descriptive character. The
main aim is to understand or define the uniqueness or character of a
particular region, which consists of natural as well as human elements.
Attention is paid also to regionalization, which covers the proper techniques
of space [delimitation](/wiki/Delimitation "Delimitation") into regions.

Regional geography is also considered as a certain approach to study in
geographical sciences (similar to [quantitative](/wiki/Quantitative_revolution
"Quantitative revolution") or [critical geographies](/wiki/Critical_geography
"Critical geography"); for more information, see [history of
geography](/wiki/History_of_geography "History of geography")).

## Human geography[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Region&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Human geography")]

[Human geography](/wiki/Human_geography "Human geography") is a branch of
geography that focuses on the study of patterns and processes that shape human
interaction with various discrete environments. It encompasses
[human](/wiki/Human "Human"), [political](/wiki/Politics "Politics"),
[cultural](/wiki/Culture "Culture"), [social](/wiki/Social_issues "Social
issues"), and [economic](/wiki/Economics "Economics") aspects among others
that are often clearly delineated. While the major focus of human geography is
not the physical landscape of the Earth (see [physical
geography](/wiki/Physical_geography "Physical geography")), it is hardly
possible to discuss human geography without referring to the physical
landscape on which human activities are being played out, and [environmental
geography](/wiki/Environmental_geography "Environmental geography") is
emerging as a link between the two. Regions of human geography can be divided
into many broad categories:

  * [Cultural geography](/wiki/Cultural_geography "Cultural geography")
  * [Demography](/wiki/Demography "Demography")
  * [Development geography](/wiki/Development_geography "Development geography")
  * [Economic geography](/wiki/Economic_geography "Economic geography")
  * [Ethnography](/wiki/Ethnography "Ethnography")
  * [Geopolitics](/wiki/Geopolitics "Geopolitics")
  * [Health geography](/wiki/Health_geography "Health geography")
  * [Historical geography](/wiki/Historical_geography "Historical geography")
  * [Language geography](/wiki/Language_geography "Language geography")
  * [Religion geography](/wiki/Religion_geography "Religion geography")
  * [Social geography](/wiki/Social_geography "Social geography")
  * [Time geography](/wiki/Time_geography "Time geography")
  * [Tourism geography](/wiki/Tourism_geography "Tourism geography")
  * [Transportation geography](/wiki/Transportation_geography "Transportation geography")
  * [Urban geography](/wiki/Urban_geography "Urban geography")
  * [Media Geography](/w/index.php?title=Media_Geography&action=edit&redlink=1 "Media Geography \(page does not exist\)")

### Historical regions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Region&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Historical regions")]

Main article: [Historical region](/wiki/Historical_region "Historical region")

The field of [historical geography](/wiki/Historical_geography "Historical
geography") involves the study of human history as it relates to places and
[regions](/wiki/Historical_region "Historical region") or the study of how
places and regions have changed over time.

[D. W. Meinig](/wiki/D._W._Meinig "D. W. Meinig"), a historical geographer of
America, describes many historical regions in his book _The Shaping of
America: A Geographical Perspective on 500 Years of History_. For example, in
identifying European "source regions" in early American colonization efforts,
he defines and describes the _Northwest European Atlantic Protestant Region_ ,
which includes sub-regions such as the "Western Channel Community", which
itself is made of sub-regions such as the _English[West
Country](/wiki/West_Country "West Country")_ of [Cornwall](/wiki/Cornwall
"Cornwall"), [Devon](/wiki/Devon "Devon"), [Somerset](/wiki/Somerset
"Somerset"), and [Dorset](/wiki/Dorset "Dorset").

In describing historic regions of America, Meinig writes of "The Great
Fishery" off the coast of Newfoundland and New England, an oceanic region that
includes the [Grand Banks](/wiki/Grand_Banks "Grand Banks"). He rejects
regions traditionally used in describing American history, like [New
France](/wiki/New_France "New France"), "West Indies", the [Middle
Colonies](/wiki/Middle_Colonies "Middle Colonies"), and the individual
colonies themselves ([Province of Maryland](/wiki/Province_of_Maryland
"Province of Maryland"), for example). Instead he writes of "discrete
colonization areas," which may be named after colonies but rarely adhere
strictly to political boundaries. Historic regions of this type Meinig writes
about include "Greater New England" and its major sub-regions of "Plymouth,"
"New Haven shores" (including parts of Long Island), "Rhode Island" (or
"Narragansett Bay"), "the Piscataqua," "Massachusetts Bay," "Connecticut
Valley," and to a lesser degree, regions in the sphere of influence of Greater
New England, "Acadia" (Nova Scotia), "Newfoundland and The Fishery/The Banks."

Other examples of historical regions include Iroquoia, [Ohio
Country](/wiki/Ohio_Country "Ohio Country"), [Illinois
Country](/wiki/Illinois_Country "Illinois Country"), and [Rupert's
Land](/wiki/Rupert%27s_Land "Rupert's Land").

### Tourism region[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Region&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Tourism region")]

Main article: [Tourism region](/wiki/Tourism_region "Tourism region")

A tourism region is a geographical region that has been designated by a
governmental organization or [tourism bureau](/wiki/Tourism_bureau "Tourism
bureau") as having common cultural or environmental characteristics. These
regions are often named after a geographical, former, or current
administrative region or may have a name created for [tourism](/wiki/Tourism
"Tourism") purposes. The names often evoke certain positive qualities of the
area and suggest a coherent tourism experience to visitors. Countries, states,
provinces, and other administrative regions are often carved up into tourism
regions to facilitate attracting visitors.

Some of the more famous tourism regions based on historical or current
administrative regions include [Tuscany](/wiki/Tuscany "Tuscany")[1] in Italy
and [Yucatán](/wiki/Yucat%C3%A1n_\(state\) "Yucatán \(state\)")[2] in Mexico.
Famous examples of regions created by a government or tourism bureau include
the [United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom")'s [Lake
District](/wiki/Lake_District "Lake District")[3] and [California's Wine
Country](/wiki/Wine_Country_\(California\) "Wine Country \(California\)").[4]
great plains region

### Natural resource
regions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Region&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section:
Natural resource regions")]

[Natural resources](/wiki/Natural_resource "Natural resource") often occur in
distinct regions. Natural resource regions can be a topic of physical
geography or environmental geography, but also have a strong element of human
geography and economic geography. A coal region, for example, is a physical or
geomorphological region, but its development and exploitation can make it into
an economic and a cultural region. Some examples of natural resource regions
include the [Rumaila Field](/wiki/Rumaila_Field "Rumaila Field"), the oil
field that lies along the border or Iraq and Kuwait and played a role in the
[Gulf War](/wiki/Gulf_War "Gulf War"); the [Coal Region](/wiki/Coal_Region
"Coal Region") of Pennsylvania, which is a historical region as well as a
cultural, physical, and natural resource region; the [South Wales
Coalfield](/wiki/South_Wales_Coalfield "South Wales Coalfield"), which like
Pennsylvania's coal region is a historical, cultural, and natural region; the
[Kuznetsk Basin](/wiki/Kuznetsk_Basin "Kuznetsk Basin"), a similarly important
coal mining region in Russia; [Kryvbas](/wiki/Kryvbas "Kryvbas"), the economic
and iron ore mining region of Ukraine; and the [James Bay
Project](/wiki/James_Bay_Project "James Bay Project"), a large region of
Quebec where one of the largest hydroelectric systems in the world has been
developed.

### Religious regions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Region&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Religious regions")]

Sometimes a region associated with a religion is given a name, like
[Christendom](/wiki/Christendom "Christendom"), a term with medieval and
renaissance connotations of Christianity as a sort of social and political
[polity](/wiki/Body_Politic "Body Politic"). The term [Muslim
world](/wiki/Muslim_world "Muslim world") is sometimes used to refer to the
region of the world where Islam is dominant. These broad terms are very vague
when used to describe regions.

Within some religions there are clearly defined regions. The [Roman Catholic
Church](/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Church "Roman Catholic Church"), the [Church of
England](/wiki/List_of_Church_of_England_dioceses "List of Church of England
dioceses"), the [Eastern Orthodox Church](/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church
"Eastern Orthodox Church"), and others, define ecclesiastical regions with
names such as [diocese](/wiki/Diocese "Diocese"), [eparchy](/wiki/Eparchy
"Eparchy"), [ecclesiastical provinces](/wiki/Ecclesiastical_Province
"Ecclesiastical Province"), and [parish](/wiki/Parish "Parish").

For example, the United States is divided into 32 Roman Catholic
[ecclesiastical
provinces](/wiki/List_of_the_Roman_Catholic_dioceses_of_the_United_States
"List of the Roman Catholic dioceses of the United States"). The [Lutheran
Church–Missouri Synod](/wiki/Lutheran_Church%E2%80%93Missouri_Synod "Lutheran
Church–Missouri Synod") is organized into 33 geographic _districts_ , which
are subdivided into _circuits_ (the [Atlantic District
(LCMS)](/wiki/Atlantic_District_\(LCMS\) "Atlantic District \(LCMS\)"), for
example). [The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day
Saints](/wiki/The_Church_of_Jesus_Christ_of_Latter-day_Saints "The Church of
Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints") uses regions similar to dioceses and
parishes, but uses terms like [ward](/wiki/Ward_\(LDS_Church\) "Ward \(LDS
Church\)") and [stake](/wiki/Stake_\(Mormonism\) "Stake \(Mormonism\)").

### Political regions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Region&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Political regions")]

See also: [Administrative divisions](/wiki/Administrative_divisions
"Administrative divisions")

In the field of [political geography](/wiki/Political_geography "Political
geography"), regions tend to be based on political units such as [sovereign
states](/wiki/Sovereign_state "Sovereign state"); subnational units such as
administrative regions, [provinces](/wiki/Province "Province"), [states (in
the United States)](/wiki/U.S._state "U.S. state"), [counties](/wiki/County
"County"), [townships](/wiki/Township "Township"),
[territories](/wiki/Territory_\(country_subdivision\) "Territory \(country
subdivision\)"), etc.; and multinational groupings, including formally defined
units such as the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union"), the
[Association of Southeast Asian
Nations](/wiki/Association_of_Southeast_Asian_Nations "Association of
Southeast Asian Nations"), and [NATO](/wiki/NATO "NATO"), as well as
informally defined regions such as the [Third World](/wiki/Third_World "Third
World"), [Western Europe](/wiki/Western_Europe "Western Europe"), and the
Middle East.

### Administrative
regions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Region&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section:
Administrative regions")]

Further information: [Administrative division](/wiki/Administrative_division
"Administrative division")

The word "region" is taken from the [Latin](/wiki/Latin "Latin") _regio_
(derived from _regere_ , to rule), and a number of countries have borrowed the
term as the formal name for a type of subnational entity (e.g., the
[_región_](/wiki/Regions_of_Chile "Regions of Chile"), used in
[Chile](/wiki/Chile "Chile")). In English, the word is also used as the
conventional translation for equivalent terms in other languages (e.g., the
[_область_](/wiki/Oblasts_of_Russia "Oblasts of Russia")
(_[oblast](/wiki/Oblast "Oblast")_), used in Russia alongside a broader term
_регион_).

The following countries use the term "region" (or its [cognate](/wiki/Cognate
"Cognate")) as the name of a type of subnational administrative unit:

  * [Belgium](/wiki/Regions_of_Belgium "Regions of Belgium") (in French, _région_ ; in German, _Region_ ; the [Dutch](/wiki/Dutch_language "Dutch language") term _gewest_ is often translated as "region")
  * [Chad](/wiki/Regions_of_Chad "Regions of Chad") (__région__ , effective from 2002)
  * [Chile](/wiki/Regions_of_Chile "Regions of Chile") (_región_)
  * [Côte d'Ivoire](/wiki/Regions_of_C%C3%B4te_d%27Ivoire "Regions of Côte d'Ivoire") (_région_)
  * [Denmark](/wiki/Regions_of_Denmark "Regions of Denmark") (effective from 2007)
  * [England](/wiki/Regions_of_England "Regions of England") (not the United Kingdom as a whole)
  * [Eritrea](/wiki/Regions_of_Eritrea "Regions of Eritrea")
  * [France](/wiki/Regions_of_France "Regions of France") (_région_)
  * [Ghana](/wiki/Regions_of_Ghana "Regions of Ghana")
  * [Guinea](/wiki/Regions_of_Guinea "Regions of Guinea") (_région_)
  * [Guinea-Bissau](/wiki/Regions_of_Guinea-Bissau "Regions of Guinea-Bissau") (_região_)
  * [Guyana](/wiki/Regions_of_Guyana "Regions of Guyana")
  * [Hungary](/wiki/Regions_of_Hungary "Regions of Hungary") (_régió_)
  * [Italy](/wiki/Regions_of_Italy "Regions of Italy") (_regione_)
  * [Madagascar](/wiki/Regions_of_Madagascar "Regions of Madagascar") (_région_)
  * [Mali](/wiki/Regions_of_Mali "Regions of Mali") (_région_)
  * [Malta](/wiki/Regions_of_Malta "Regions of Malta") (_reġjun_)
  * [Namibia](/wiki/Regions_of_Namibia "Regions of Namibia")
  * [New Zealand](/wiki/Regions_of_New_Zealand "Regions of New Zealand")
  * [Peru](/wiki/Regions_of_Peru "Regions of Peru") (_región_)
  * [Portugal](/wiki/List_of_regions_and_sub-regions_of_Portugal "List of regions and sub-regions of Portugal") (_região_)
  * [Philippines](/wiki/Regions_of_the_Philippines "Regions of the Philippines") (_rehiyon_)
  * [Senegal](/wiki/Regions_of_Senegal "Regions of Senegal") (_région_)
  * [Tanzania](/wiki/Regions_of_Tanzania "Regions of Tanzania")
  * [Togo](/wiki/Regions_of_Togo "Regions of Togo") (_région_)
  * [Trinidad and Tobago](/wiki/Regional_Corporations_and_Municipalities_of_Trinidad_and_Tobago "Regional Corporations and Municipalities of Trinidad and Tobago") (_Regional Corporation_)

The Canadian [province](/wiki/Provinces_and_territories_of_Canada "Provinces
and territories of Canada") of [Québec](/wiki/List_of_Quebec_regions "List of
Quebec regions") also uses the "administrative region" (_région
administrative_).

Scotland had [local government
regions](/wiki/Local_government_areas_of_Scotland_1973_to_1996 "Local
government areas of Scotland 1973 to 1996") from 1975 to 1996.

In Spain the official name of the [autonomous
community](/wiki/Autonomous_community "Autonomous community") of
[Murcia](/wiki/Region_of_Murcia "Region of Murcia") is _Región de Murcia_.
Also, some single-province autonomous communities such as
[Madrid](/wiki/Madrid "Madrid") use the term _región_ interchangeably with
_comunidad autónoma_.

Two [län](/wiki/L%C3%A4n_of_Sweden "Län of Sweden") (counties) in Sweden are
officially called 'regions': [Skåne](/wiki/Sk%C3%A5ne "Skåne") and [Västra
Götaland](/wiki/V%C3%A4stra_G%C3%B6taland "Västra Götaland"), and there is
currently a controversial proposal to divide the rest of Sweden into large
[regions](/wiki/Regions_of_Sweden "Regions of Sweden"), replacing the current
counties.

The government of the [Philippines](/wiki/Regions_of_the_Philippines "Regions
of the Philippines") uses the term "region" (in
[Filipino](/wiki/Filipino_language "Filipino language"), _rehiyon_) when it's
necessary to group provinces, the primary administrative subdivision of the
country. This is also the case in [Brazil](/wiki/Brazil "Brazil"), which
groups its primary administrative divisions (_estados_ ; "states") into
_grandes regiões_ ([greater regions](/wiki/Regions_of_Brazil "Regions of
Brazil")) for statistical purposes, while Russia uses _экономические районы_
([economic regions](/wiki/Economic_regions_of_Russia "Economic regions of
Russia")) in a similar way, as does
[Romania](/wiki/Development_regions_of_Romania "Development regions of
Romania") and [Venezuela](/wiki/Administrative_regions_of_Venezuela
"Administrative regions of Venezuela").

The [government of Singapore](/wiki/Government_of_Singapore "Government of
Singapore") makes use of the term "[region](/wiki/Regions_of_Singapore
"Regions of Singapore")" for its own administrative purposes.

The following countries use an administrative subdivision conventionally
referred to as a region in English:

  * [Bulgaria](/wiki/Oblasts_of_Bulgaria "Oblasts of Bulgaria"), which uses the _област_ (_oblast_)
  * [Russia](/wiki/Oblasts_of_Russia "Oblasts of Russia"), which uses the _область_ (_oblast '_), and for some regions the [_край_](/wiki/Krais_of_Russia "Krais of Russia") (_[krai](/wiki/Krai "Krai")_)
  * [Ukraine](/wiki/Subdivisions_of_Ukraine "Subdivisions of Ukraine"), which uses the _область_ (_oblast '_)
  * [Slovakia](/wiki/Regions_of_Slovakia "Regions of Slovakia") (_kraj_)

China has five 自治区 (_zìzhìqū_) and two 特別行政區 (or 特别行政区; _tèbiéxíngzhèngqū_),
which are translated as "[autonomous region](/wiki/Autonomous_region_of_China
"Autonomous region of China")" and "[special administrative
region](/wiki/Special_Administrative_Region_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China
"Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China")",
respectively.

#### Local administrative
regions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Region&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section:
Local administrative regions")]

There are many relatively small regions based on local government agencies
such as districts, agencies, or regions. In general, they are all regions in
the general sense of being bounded spatial units. Examples include electoral
districts such as [Washington's 6th congressional
district](/wiki/Washington%27s_6th_congressional_district "Washington's 6th
congressional district") and [Tennessee's 1st congressional
district](/wiki/Tennessee%27s_1st_congressional_district "Tennessee's 1st
congressional district"); school districts such as [Granite School
District](/wiki/Granite_School_District "Granite School District") and [Los
Angeles Unified School District](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Unified_School_District
"Los Angeles Unified School District"); economic districts such as the [Reedy
Creek Improvement District](/wiki/Reedy_Creek_Improvement_District "Reedy
Creek Improvement District"); metropolitan areas such as the [Seattle
metropolitan area](/wiki/Seattle_metropolitan_area "Seattle metropolitan
area"), and metropolitan districts such as the [Metropolitan Water Reclamation
District of Greater
Chicago](/wiki/Metropolitan_Water_Reclamation_District_of_Greater_Chicago
"Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago"), the [Las Vegas-
Clark County Library District](/wiki/Las_Vegas-Clark_County_Library_District
"Las Vegas-Clark County Library District"), the [Metropolitan Police
Service](/wiki/Metropolitan_Police_Service "Metropolitan Police Service") of
[Greater London](/wiki/Greater_London "Greater London"), as well as other
local districts like the [York Rural Sanitary
District](/wiki/York_Rural_Sanitary_District "York Rural Sanitary District"),
the [Delaware River Port Authority](/wiki/Delaware_River_Port_Authority
"Delaware River Port Authority"), the [Nassau County Soil and Water
Conservation
District](/wiki/Nassau_County_Soil_and_Water_Conservation_District "Nassau
County Soil and Water Conservation District"), and
[C-TRAN](/wiki/C-TRAN_\(Washington\) "C-TRAN \(Washington\)").

### Traditional or informal
regions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Region&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section:
Traditional or informal regions")]

The traditional territorial divisions of some countries are also commonly
rendered in English as "regions". These informal divisions do not form the
basis of the modern administrative divisions of these countries, but still
define and delimit local regional identity and sense of belonging. Examples
include:

  * [Finland](/wiki/Regions_of_Finland "Regions of Finland")
  * [Japan](/wiki/Regions_of_Japan "Regions of Japan")

### Functional regions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Region&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Functional regions")]

Functional regions are usually understood to be the areas organised by the
horizontal functional relations (flows, interactions) that are maximised
within a region and minimised across its borders so that the principles of
internal cohesiveness and external separation regarding spatial interactions
are met (see, for instance, Farmer and Fotheringham, 2011[5]; Klapka, Halas,
2016[6]; Smart, 1974[7]). A functional region is not an abstract spatial
concept, but to a certain extent it can be regarded as a reflection of the
spatial behaviour of individuals in a geographic space. The functional region
is conceived as a general concept while its inner structure, inner spatial
flows, and interactions need not necessarily show any regular pattern, only
selfcontainment. The concept of self-containment remains the only crucial
defining characteristic of a functional region. Nodal regions, functional
urban regions, daily urban systems, local labour-market areas (LLMAs), or
travel-to-work areas (TTWAs) are considered to be special instances of a
general functional region that need to fulfil some specific conditions
regarding, for instance, the character of the region-organising interaction or
the presence of urban cores, (Halas et al., 2015[8]).

In military usage, a region is shorthand for the name of a military
[formation](/wiki/Military_organization#Commands,_formations,_and_units
"Military organization") larger than an [Army Group](/wiki/Army_group "Army
group") and smaller than an [Army Theater](/wiki/Theater_\(warfare\) "Theater
\(warfare\)") or simply Theater. The full name of the military formation is
Army Region. The size of an Army Region can vary widely but is generally
somewhere between about 1 million and 3 million soldiers. Two or more Army
Regions could make up an Army Theater. An Army Region is typically commanded
by a full [General](/wiki/General "General") (US four stars), a [Field
Marshal](/wiki/Field_Marshal "Field Marshal"), or [General of the
Army](/wiki/General_of_the_Army "General of the Army") (US five stars), or
[Generalissimo](/wiki/Generalissimo "Generalissimo") (Soviet Union). Due to
the large size of this formation, its use is rarely employed. Some of the very
few examples of an Army Region are each of the Eastern, Western, and southern
(mostly in Italy) fronts in Europe during [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II
"World War II"). The military map unit symbol for this echelon of formation
(see [Military organization](/wiki/Military_organization "Military
organization") and [APP-6A](/wiki/APP-6A "APP-6A")) consists of six Xs.

### Media geography[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Region&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Media geography")]

Media geography is a spatio-temporal understanding, brought through different
gadgets of media, nowadays, media became inevitable at different proportions
and everyone supposed to consumed at different gravity. The spatial attributes
are studied with the help of media outputs in shape of images which are
contested in nature and pattern as well where politics is inseparable. Media
geography is giving spatial understanding of mediated image.

qa.question: what is the meaning of region in english
